awd_titl_txt: The Guard Cell as a Paradigm to Dissect the Role of the Actin Cytoskeleton in Plant Immunity
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants respond to the environment by utilizing a number of preformed and inducible signaling processes; interestingly, many of these responses share a number of common features. For example, plants respond to stresses imposed by limitations in water availability and pathogen infection by closing stomata- specialized pores on the leaf surface that not only function in gas exchange, but also are primary points of entry to many pathogens. Thus, in closing stomata plants restrict water loss as well as entry to potentially pathogenic microorganisms. Much in the same way that hormones regulate human cellular processes, plant hormones have been demonstrated to control plant response to changes in the environment, including the above noted response to environmental and pathogenic stressors. The long range goal of this project is to define how plant stress signals are regulated and transduced to elicit the plant immune response. To do this, the current work will use the plant stomata as a tractable marker to understand how chemical changes in a cell are perceived and ultimately transduced to regulate physical and mechanical changes in cellular movement, architecture, and shape. With this knowledge, the investigators will define the principle components that plants use to monitor their environments for potential threats, and moreover, to rapidly respond to these changes. The ultimate goal of this research is to uncover mechanisms that plants use to survive, and through dissemination of the Broader Impacts, to communicate these data to society to educate general public in the area of food production and security. 

Actin is well known for its roles in defining cell shape and powering movement of organelles and macromolecules in all eukaryotic organisms. Additionally, as a component of the immune system of both plants and animals, the actin cytoskeleton has been demonstrated to respond to a variety of pathogen-derived elicitors. However, the mechanism(s) underpinning the role of actin in plant immunity is lacking. This study will leverage recently developed methods and resources in the PIs' laboratories to define, using the stomatal guard cell as an experimental paradigm and a series of quantitative cell biology and genetic approaches, the contribution and role of actin as a key component of the plant immune network. Plant stomatal guard cells are an attractive, amenable, and biologically relevant cell type for further dissecting the role of actin dynamics in plant immunity. The work described herein will define the relationships that link basic physiological processes (e.g., hormone signaling, pathogen perception) to the host immune response. Anticipated impacts of this project are: 1) the elucidation of the processes that dynamically respond to and function as cellular switches between, pathogen, immunity, and hormone signaling; 2) the phospho-regulation and pathogen targeting of a key plant regulatory node that controls cytoskeletal organization and stomatal guard cell dynamics; and 3) a demonstration of a role for actin in critical stomatal-based signaling pathways.

por.por_cntn:
The completion of IOS-1557437 led to the advancement of knowledge which define the role of key regulators of immune signaling in plants, and more importantly, how the immune system is connected to various other processes in the cell. To define these relationships, the research team asked:

How do plants regulate overlapping processes? Specifically, how does a plant organize the contents of the cell to position it to better respond to pathogen infection?

This question – one of both fitness and organization – may hold the key towards defining how plants respond to numerous environmental stressors, and moreover, how they respond so rapidly. Over the past 4 years, the research team uncovered mechanisms (both of a genetic nature, as well as physiological) that demonstrate plants are capable of utilizing (usurping) basic physiological processes to fight pathogen infection. Excitingly, the team discovered that key immune regulators are recruited to not only defend against pathogen infection, but are themselves regulated by basic physiological processes. This observation hints at the possibility that the general health of the plant may also be a signal that fortifies immune signaling. As a guiding question throughout this project, the team hypothesized that one particular protein from plants – a kinase called CPK3 – phosphorylates both key regulators required for cell organization and movement as well as those required for immune signaling activation. Indeed, data generated through completion of the funded research demonstrated that CPK3 is required for proper actin filament organization during pathogen infection. Having identified CPK3 as the kinase that phosphorylates and regulates key immune processes in the plant, the team next investigated the effect of CPK3 on cytoskeletal organization. To do this, they generated new techniques to capture images of the cell undergoing pathogen infection. Interestingly, the outcome of this revealed that plant organize themselves differently depending on the type of stress they are encountering. This result was further supported by their observation that plants organize different cell types to restrict pathogen entry, a process they hypothesize indicate plants actively monitor for danger associated with their surroundings.

As highlighted above, the team not only completed their stated Specific Objectives, but using the outcome of this project, have advanced into new areas of research that, in the future, can readily address:

o How is plant immunity regulated by the processes that typically control movement?

o At what points of convergence between immunity and movement does their newly discovered kinase (CPK3) function?

o What is the signaling pathway – i.e., the central alarm system of the plant – that moves a signal from pathogen perception to immune activation?

As a function of the breadth and activity of actin in a suite of immune signaling processes, as well as a primer to answering the above questions, the team hypothesizes that CPK3 may also genetically interact with additional components of the plant immune system. Much like in humans, cell possess different types of cells, or antibodies, that function differently, depending on the type of threat. In this area, the team is conducting a series of experiments to understand how processes that govern movement may actually stabilize the function of the immune system. The hypothesis being that during pathogen infection, virulent pathogens disrupt immune signaling by disrupting the ability of the cell to fight.

Through the research funded by the National Science Foundation, 1 postdoctoral scholar, 2 PhD students and 2 undergraduate students receiving training and mentoring. In addition, outreach assocatied with the project served to communicate fundamental science concepts to the public through a series of community engagement programs and activites.
